news.title: Democrat Consultant Says the Quiet Part Out Loud About ‚ÄòCheating‚Äô and Elections
news.text:
For years, Democrats have gerrymandered themselves supermajorities in various blue states, and then cried like babies the second that Republicans fought back. Somehow, it‚Äôs always ‚Äúcheating‚Äù when Republicans do it, but it‚Äôs fair game when Democrats do it.

That was the message from left-wing political consultant Tezlyn Figaro on CNN‚Äôs NewsNight on Friday, and she wasn‚Äôt even being subtle about it. According to Figaro, cheating only exists as a political concept when Republicans do it. When Democrats engage in the same behavior, it magically transforms into something noble, defensive, and totally justified.

Figaro opened with a sweeping declaration that left no room for nuance or evidence. ‚ÄúAnd one would argue that if Republicans can‚Äôt win in Texas, they cheat,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf Republicans can‚Äôt win, they cheat. They cheat. They cheat by changing the maps.‚Äù

From her perspective, Republicans lose elections. Republicans respond by cheating. Case closed. That‚Äôs when Scott Jennings jumped in.

‚ÄúSo, you‚Äôre saying it was illegal in what they did?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúWell, one would argue that,‚Äù Figaro insisted. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why they put the whole lawsuit piece up.‚Äù

Jennings kept going because that is what happens when someone uses the word ‚Äúcheating‚Äù in a legal context. He asked whether the same logic applied elsewhere. ‚ÄúIs it illegal in Illinois?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be too,‚Äù Figaro replied.

‚ÄúIs it illegal in Democrat states?‚Äù Jennings asked.

‚ÄúIt could be, yes. It could be.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo, you‚Äôre saying the entire political system is just cheating?‚Äù

Here‚Äôs where Figaro showed what she really meant. ‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs not what I said. I said if Republicans can‚Äôt win, they cheat. Not the entire political system, just Republicans. But it‚Äôs okay.‚Äù

There it was. Just Republicans cheat. And not just by redistricting‚Ä¶ but by appointing judges too. Figaro spiraled into a Kamala Harris-esque word salad about courts, lawsuits, and Donald Trump secretly running the judiciary. ‚ÄúWill it survive court challenge because it was Trump‚Äôs folks in the court. He runs the court system as well. That‚Äôs also called cheating.‚Äù

ICYMI: How Long Before Tim Walz Is Indicted?

In other words, Republicans cheat by redistricting. Republicans cheat by appointing judges. Republicans cheat by winning court cases. Democrats file lawsuits forever because, you know‚Ä¶ Virtue! Democracy!

Even CNN host Abby Phillip gently pointed out the obvious: ‚ÄúI mean Democrats are also doing now the same thing Republicans are doing with these ‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat Newsom did, yes,‚Äù Figaro jumped in.

Jennings went for the kill shot: ‚ÄúWas it cheating in California?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fire for fire,‚Äù Figaro said.

Jennings, refusing to let her dodge, asked again: ‚ÄúIs it cheating?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs responding,‚Äù she replied.

‚ÄúYou said he‚Äôs cheating.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could call it cheating if that‚Äôs what you want to call it.‚Äù

Jennings finally translated her argument into plain English: ‚ÄúSo, it‚Äôs cheating for Republicans and it‚Äôs okay for Democrat.‚Äù

Figaro protested, then immediately proved his point: ‚ÄúI said that if Republicans can‚Äôt win, they cheat. And so what Newsom did is, he countered that. He countered it, whatever you want to call it. He countered cheating.‚Äù

That is the left‚Äôs worldview in a nutshell. Republican actions equal cheating by definition. Democrat actions equal counter-cheating. The rules stay the same. The judgment changes based on party.

Jennings summed it up with visible exasperation: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking in circles again. Are you dizzy?‚Äù

üö® HOLY CRAP! Scott Jennings EMBARRASSES liberal on CNN who whines Republicans are "CHEATING" by redistricting for 2026"You talk in CIRCLES, are you DIZZY!?" ü§£LIB: If Republicans can't win Texas, they cheat!SCOTT: How? So you're saying it was illegal what they did in‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/MGqaofRFjL‚Äî Eric Daugherty (@EricLDaugh) December 27, 2025

This is no different than Democrats abusing the filibuster when they were in the minority, calling it a critical tool to protect the minority party. Then, when Republicans responded in kind, Democrats nuked the filibuster. Time and again, Democrats make it clear that they judge the morality and legality of the system based on whether it benefits them at a particular moment. Power matters more than consistency. For Democrats, the moral compass only points in their direction.

Your membership unlocks exclusive content, podcasts, and an ad-free experience. Start the new year standing with a media outlet that fights for the truth.

The WEIRDEST celebrity relationships of 2025 from Chris Hughes and JoJo Siwa to Billy Ray Cyrus and Elizabeth Hurley and Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau

Have YOU got a story? Email tips@dailymail.com 
By AMELIA WYNNE, SHOWBUSINESS REPORTER 
 Published:10:07 EST, 28 December 2025 |Updated:10:58 EST, 28 December 2025 

The year 2025 has certainly been filled with a host of very unexpected romantic relationships.
Shock pairings have emerged into the spotlight out of nowhere including between Chris Hughes and JoJo Siwa, Billy Ray Cyrus and Elizabeth Hurley and Katy Perry and former prime minister of Canada Justin Trudeau.
JoJo, 22, and Chris, 32, sent shockwaves through the Showbiz world when their close bond formed on Celebrity Big Brother back in April.
They are still going strong all these months later and have even hinted at marriage in the future.
In addition Hollywood siren Sydney Sweeney raised eyebrows this autumn when she began dating controversial music mogul Scooter Braun.
While just this month Ellie Goulding, 38, revealed she was expecting a baby with her toyboy lover Beau Minniear, 28, - whose criminal record has since been revealed. 
So which shock couples have popped up in 2025?

The WEIRDEST celebrity relationships of 2025 from Chris Hughes and JoJo Siwa (pictured) to Billy Ray Cyrus and Elizabeth Hurley and Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau

JoJo Siwa and Chris Hughes 
Eight months on from starting their relationship, JoJo and Chris recently reflected on their whirlwind romance. 
The former Love Island star and dancer met in the Celebrity Big Brother house back in April, and in the days after the series ended, they started dating. 
Their chemistry became a talking point on the show as JoJo was in a relationship with her now ex Kath Ebbs at the time. 
When Chris and JoJo then made their relationship public, it caused a stir on social media, with Big Brother viewers questioning if it was just a showmance to boost their profiles. 
But the pair have vehemently denied the accusations and insist their love is real in a new interview. 
'I think anyone who meets someone on television, I don't think it matters who it would be, there would be some people who would doubt it. I don't think you can read into that too much,' JoJo told The Sun.

Join the debate

View gallery

Their chemistry became a talking point on the show as JoJo was in a relationship with her now ex Kath Ebbs at the time 
Chris added: 'We're just bobbing and weaving and ducking and diving, kicking along.'
The television personality isn't afraid of fast-paced relationships. He rose to fame on ITV2 dating show Love Island back in 2017, where he had a rollercoaster romance with Olivia Attwood, 34. 

Which 2025 celebrity couple shocked YOU the most?

Shailene Woodley and Lucas Bravo

His romance with JoJo has moved just as fast, with the couple dividing time between their homes in the US and the UK.
Talking about the foundations of their love story, Chris insisted while they didn't spend a long time dating, he really got to know the 'ins and outs' of JoJo in the three weeks they spent in the Big Brother house. 
He said: 'We spent three weeks with each other. I know we weren't together then but it's been a long time.' 
Elsewhere in the interview, JoJo revealed a dealbreaker for them in making their relationship work is only accepting job offers which don't put their romance in jeopardy. 
She added: 'Something important to both of us, is that nothing comes between us, is that nothing makes anything stressful or feels that we have to do something.' 
Their gushing interview came after JoJo's ex Kath Ebbs announced she is engaged to new love Tilly Lucas-Rodd. 
Kath was left heartbroken in August when the Dance Moms star appeared on Celebrity Big Brother in the UK, during which she formed a flirtatious bond with Chris. 
At the CBB after-party, it was revealed that JoJo dumped Kath - leaving the latter 'disorientated, numb and in shock' - before the star started her romance with Chris.
They have now found love with Tilly, with the pair announcing their engagement after going public with their romance in July.
Billy Ray Cyrus and Elizabeth Hurley

View gallery

Elizabeth shocked fans in April when she announced her relationship with Achy Breaky singer Billy Ray 
Elizabeth shocked fans in April when she announced her relationship with Achy Breaky singer Billy Ray.
She posted a snap of them both on Easter Sunday as she leaned in for a kiss and couldn't keep a smile off her face.
Back in May, Elizabeth and Billy made their red carpet debut in Rome while attending the Orizzonti | Rosso Exhibition Opening Dinner together - with her son Damian also joining the couple.
The same month, The Royals actress made an appearance at the Breast Cancer Research Foundation 2025 Hot Pink Party in New York City - and gave an update about their relationship during an exclusive interview with DailyMail.com.
She gushed that she is 'very happy in my new relationship' and added, 'Billy's a lovely man and we make each other very happy.'
The pair's relationship began following his divorce from Firerose - and his third marriage.
He had met Elizabeth on set of the 2022 movie Christmas In Paradise and as he was navigating through the split from Firerose, he received a message from the actress.

View gallery

She posted a snap of them both on Easter Sunday as she leaned in for a kiss and couldn't keep a smile off her face 
Elizabeth's son Damian recently rushed to the defence of Billy Ray, branding him the 'sweetest man' as he hit back at 'untrue stories'. 
'I've been in the public eyes since the day I was born and rarely comment on anything written about me or my family,' Damian penned, before slamming recent 'untrue' stories.
'For the record: I adore @billyraycyrus and think he's one of the sweetest men I've ever met. I love seeing my mom so happy.'
He added that Billy's kids are 'adorable' while also expressing that the families 'get along beautifully.'
Damian - who is the son of Elizabeth and biological dad Steve Bing - continued to explain that he is part of a 'modern family,' including his former stepfather Arun Nayar. 
Arun was previously married to the Gossip Girl alum from 2007 until their divorce was finalized in 2011. 
After giving a shoutout to his step siblings, the media personality added, 'I feel blessed every day to be surrounded by so much love and support. I'm grateful for the truth we live, despite the stories others try to write for us.' 
Billy was seemingly moved by Damian's kind words reposted the message to his own Instagram stories and wrote, 'Love you D Man.' 

View gallery

Last month the couple cozied up on the red carpet as they attended the 59th Annual CMA Awards in Nashville
However, this is not the first time that the model publicly showed his support for his mother's romance with the actor. 
When the pair first debuted their relationship over Easter weekend, he jumped to the comment section to share a black heart emoji. 
Also in April, sources told The Sun: 'Damian has met Billy and is a really big fan of his. They hit it off when they hung out on set. 
'All he wants is for his mum to be happy and he saw their spark straight away and is delighted they are now giving it a go.'
Elizabeth revealed her plans to celebrate Christmas in the U.K. with Billy during LYMA's Power Women series. 
She reflected on how she had been content being single but when she met the singer, the actress 'felt incredibly comfortable and natural and easy from the first second.'
The star also explained, 'I always spend Christmas in the countryside in Herefordshire, where I live. Me and my siblings, everyone always comes to me.
'There are a lot of people there, we eat a lot. We do the typical English thing of eating quality streets, watching TV and going out with the dogs.
'So all I want for Christmas this year is that Billy, my new boyfriend, enjoys his first English Christmas.'
She added, 'He spent the whole summer with us, but I really do hope that he integrates with us, loves it, enjoys it and doesn't laugh at us for eating so many quality streets and lying on the sofa.
'All I want is peace, happiness and being relaxed, having a laugh with friends and family.'
Last month while talking to The Sunday Times, Elizabeth shared that Billy is a big fan of England. 
'He lives 40 minutes outside of Nashville. It's so beautiful. Funnily enough, it actually looks a lot like England. Probably the equivalent of Surrey.' 
Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau

View gallery

Katy Perry's new romance with Justin Trudeau sent shockwaves through the Showbiz world when it was revealed earlier this year 
Katy Perry's new romance with Justin Trudeau sent shockwaves through the Showbiz world when it was revealed earlier this year. 
The Roar songstress finally went Instagram official with her boyfriend recently after months of fevered public speculation on their relationship.
The former Canadian Prime Minister, 53, reposted a photo of him and the pop star posing with former Japanese prime minister Fumio Kishida and his wife Yuko Kishida on December 4. 
Their meeting took place earlier this month, with Trudeau and Perry already in Japan for her Lifetimes Tour show, though Perry quickly faced backlash for the 'inappropriate' mini skirt she wore to what fans viewed as a diplomatic-style meeting.
However she has now brushed off the blowback and zeroed in her focus on the romantic aspect of her latest trip to Japan.
She soon after shared a selfie of her and Trudeau cuddling up to one another as they strolled through a park together amid the changing autumn colors.
The photo was part of an album that also featured a black and white video of Perry trying uni for the first time as Trudeau looked proudly on beside her.
Meanwhile Trudeau similarly shrugged off the backlash to his and Perry's photo with the Kishidas, re-sharing the image from Kishida's X account, writing: 'Great to see you @kishida230. Katy and I were so glad to have the chance to sit down with you and Yuko.'
'Thank you, Fumio, for your friendship and your continued commitment to both the international rules-based order and to a better future for everyone.'
Their trip marked the latest international outing for the duo, who first sparked dating rumors in July following Perry's split from ex-fianc√© Orlando Bloom, 48.
After weeks of speculation, they made their official debut as a couple in September in Paris, stepping out hand-in-hand during a romantic evening in the French capital.
A source previously told People that Perry and Trudeau have been 'making plans for the holidays' and that the pop star is navigating a whirlwind schedule as she prepares to wrap up her Lifetimes Tour.
'Without exaggeration, this year has been a whirlwind for her. She hasn't even had time to really think about her life after the tour,' the insider shared.

View gallery

The Roar songstress finally went Instagram official with her boyfriend recently after months of fevered public speculation on their relationship 

View gallery

The former Canadian Prime Minister, 53, reposted a photo of him and the pop star posing with former Japanese prime minister Fumio Kishida and his wife Yuko Kishida on December 4 
Though her romance with Trudeau has been an exciting new chapter, the source emphasized that Perry remains focused on her five-year-old daughter Daisy Dove, whom she shares with Bloom.
'She's a single mom now and a lot of that is going to come into focus next year,' they added.
The insider also revealed that Perry is 'excited' by Trudeau, noting she is 'having a lot of fun' despite being surprised by how quickly she connected with someone new after the end of her long-term relationship with Bloom.
'Justin keeps making a big effort to see her and she's excited about it. [She has] a lot of fun with him. It's exactly what she needs right now,' the source said.
On Trudeau's side, the relationship appears to have brought a new sense of ease.
'He is a much happier person now. Stresses are greatly diminished. And he is intrigued with Katy. They have fun together, laugh a lot, talk about everything,' the source added.
Trudeau and his ex-wife Sophie Gr√©goire split in 2023; they are parents to sons Xavier, 18, and Hadrien, 11, as well as daughter Ella-Grace Margaret, 16. 
Scooter Braun and Sydney Sweeney 

View gallery

The 28-year-old Christy actress and the music executive, 44, began dating earlier this year (seen in NYC in October) 
The 28-year-old Christy actress and the music executive, 44, began dating earlier this year.
Insiders recently told The Daily Mail that the pair's romance has escalated quickly behind the scenes.
'They talk every day and see each other often, it is hot and heavy,' a source shared. 'I don't want to say the L word, but it feels like the L word.'
The source added that Braun has become a grounding presence amid Sweeney's skyrocketing fame, describing him as an 'old soul' who offers guidance as her career continues to explode.
The duo were first linked over the summer after crossing paths at Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sanchez's lavish wedding, months after Sweeney ended her engagement to longtime fianc√© Jonathan Davino. 
While early reports suggested the two were 'casually dating,' their increasingly public appearances suggest the connection may be more serious than initially believed.
A source told Entertainment Tonight that both Sweeney and Braun are keeping their relationship 'low-key.' 
'They were both overwhelmed by the backlash they received from news of them dating coming out. They thought the hate was blown out of proportion,' the insider said.
In September, the couple were seen holding hands as they had a blast during Horror Nights at Universal Studios in Hollywood.
'The attraction is she is hot as can be,' an insider told the Daily Mail. 'He gives great advice. They have what each other wants.'

View gallery

Insiders recently told The Daily Mail that the pair's romance has escalated quickly behind the scenes 
Since going public with their romance, Sweeney and Braun have been spotted enjoying dates together across the country.
Earlier this month, the two stars held hands during an excursion in New York City - shortly after her 'screaming' fight with ex-fianc√© Jonathan.
Sweeney raised eyebrows after she was seen quietly slipping into a car with her ex-fianc√© in Los Angeles. 
Photographs captured the two-time Emmy nominee ducking down in the passenger seat with Davino behind the wheel.
But their apparent amiability seemed short-lived. TMZ reported that, at one point, the star screamed: 'I don't believe you. Please leave, leave me alone.'
The former couple called off their engagement, earlier this year, after about seven years together. 
Ellie Goulding and Beau Minniear 

View gallery

Actor Beau, 28, and Ellie confirmed they were dating earlier this year, as their unlikely romance was revealed 
Actor Beau, 28, and Ellie confirmed they were dating earlier this year, as their unlikely romance was revealed. 
Recently the singer, 38, revealed she was pregnant as she showed off her baby bump at the Fashion Awards in London.
Soon after, The Daily Mail then exclusively revealed that in 2018, aged 20, Beau was arrested in Palm Beach, Florida, where he was living at the time. 
The incident led to him being charged with three offences: robbery without a firearm, felony battery resulting in a serious bodily injury, and marijuana possession.
According to documents filed by the West Palm Beach Police Department, Beau and two other young men were taken into custody after an altercation on a street at around 2.30am.
A 36-year-old man claimed to have been kicked and punched multiple times by a group of attackers, while lying on the ground, leaving him with a fractured elbow and bleeding nose.
According to the police records, he claimed that they also ripped off his trousers and stole his wallet, which was found in the possession of one of the men Beau was with when they were arrested.

View gallery

Recently the singer, 38, revealed she was pregnant as she showed off her baby bump at the Fashion Awards in London 
According to address details filed with the police, the victim ‚Äì who also has a criminal record ‚Äì was homeless at the time.
In a mugshot taken after his arrest, Beau, dressed in a blue-and-purple plaid shirt, looks downcast and remorseful, his hair hanging greasily over his forehead. He was the only one in the group charged with a drugs offence, having been found with seven grams of marijuana in his pockets.
Having served two days behind bars at the County Jail, Beau admitted misdemeanour battery, a lesser offence than felony battery, as part of an apparent plea deal.
Appearing in front of a jury in November 2018, he was granted probation and ordered to pay $675 (¬£500) in costs.
He also had to complete a 12-hour online anger management course, and was ordered to do 75 hours of community service at a minimum of ten hours per month over the following year.
This wasn't, however, Beau's last brush with the law.
In 2020, during the Black Lives Matter riots in Los Angeles ‚Äì two days of unrest sparked by the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis, Minnesota ‚Äì he was arrested again.

View gallery

Beau appears in several raunchy scenes in Ellie's latest music video, Destiny
Along with 4,000 others, the then 23-year-old was taken into custody for breaching the 8pm curfew that had been imposed on the city to quell the violence. No further action appears to have been taken, and he was apparently released without charge.
Given that Ellie is expecting his first child, one must presume that Beau has told her about his chequered past.
The singer split from her husband Caspar Jopling, with whom she shares a four-year-old son, Arthur, in February last year. Since her relationship with Beau went public in September, the pair have holidayed together in Italy, where Beau shared online an intimate photograph of Ellie lying in an unmade hotel room bed.
He also appears in several raunchy scenes in Ellie's latest music video, Destiny.
In one, the pair passionately kiss while wearing veils over their heads; in another Ellie takes pictures of Beau's semi-naked body before straddling him. She playfully captioned a behind-the-scenes clip on her TikTok profile: 'Bring your bf [boyfriend] to work day,' adding: 'He upstaged me tbh [to be honest].'
It marks quite the change for the British songstress, who just six years ago married Eton-educated art dealer Caspar in a fairytale ceremony at York Minster.
In attendance were Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie, long-term friends of Ellie ‚Äì who is also close to Prince William and Prince Harry, with whom she was once romantically linked.
Ellie broke her silence on her pregnancy and gushed that she felt 'empowered and my absolute best' on Wednesday after her surprise bump reveal. 
She showed off her growing bump in an outfit from designer Willy Chavarria and announced her happy news.
In her first Instagram post since the reveal, she shared a series of photos from the night. 
The hitmaker wrote: 'So grateful to have attended the Fashion Awards with the visionary Willy Chavarria, wearing a look that was a little bit custom, a little bit archive. 
'Only on a night like this, could Willy be the one to empower me and make me feel my absolute bestttt.'
Ellie added: 'Thank you for a night filled with meaning, beauty, and so much heart x.' 
Shailene Woodley and Lucas Bravo 

View gallery

Shailene and Lucas seemed an unlikely pairing when it was revealed that they'd started dating earlier this year 
Shailene and Lucas seemed an unlikely pairing when it was revealed that they'd started dating earlier this year.
The Emily In Paris hunk, 37, and the actress, 34, was first spotted together in Paris this past March.
At the time, they were spotted canoodling on the France set of Lucas' show Emily in Paris. 
That same month a source told People that their romance was 'a breath of fresh air for her.'
The person also described Lucas as 'uncomplicated, kind, not pretentious and emotionally present.'
'Her friends love him,' the insider emphasized, noting that the Twisted Tale of Amanda Knox star was 'thriving.'
'It's a whole new vibe,' the source shared, later comparing Shailene's new love to her former flame Aaron Rodgers.
'It's the total opposite of her dynamic with Aaron. She's happy, light and having fun again,' the person close to the situation said. 
The Tell Me Lies actress and Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback were romantically involved from 2020 to 2022.
They eventually broke off their engagement, leaving Shailene 'heartbroken.'
In a subsequent interview with Bustle in 2024, she cryptically said, 'I fell in love over and over with unavailability.'
However in September it was reported that Shailene and Lucas had split after their six-month relationship.
They have since wiped their respective Instagram profiles clean of each other, after previously going 'official' on the app in late April.
Daily Mail reached out to the stars' reps for comment at the time.
Curtis Pritchard and Ekin-Su C√ºlc√ºloƒülu

View gallery

Curtis and Ekin-Su met on the 2025 Love Island: All Stars series and made it very close to the end of the show 

View gallery

Curtis and Ekin-Su met on the 2025 Love Island: All Stars series and made it very close to the end of the show.
Things sadly ended just three months after the South African season wrapped.
Curtis, whose brother is former Strictly star AJ Pritchard, first appeared on Love Island in 2019, where he met ex-girlfriend Maura Higgins. 
He returned earlier this year for Love Island: All Stars, dating Ekin-Su until their split in July, and has not been linked to anyone since.
Announcing the split on Instagram, she wrote: 'I wanted to share that Curtis and I have decided to go our separate ways. 
'It's been a really tough decision, but one made with a lot of love and respect for one another.
'He's an incredible person and I'll always cherish the memories we made both in an out of the villa.'
At the time many fans branded them a showmance and said they seemed a very unlikely pair. 
It came following her split from her boyfriend Davide before going on to have a rocky stint in Celebrity Big Brother. 
The couple had a turbulent 18-month relationship since they first met in the Love Island villa in 2022, going on to win the show's ¬£50,000 prize money together.
Zara McDermott and Louis Tomlinson

Zara and Louis began dating early this year after her split from Sam Thompson

news.title: What to expect from the California governor race in 2026?
news.text:
The special election on redistricting has been certified. The closely watched decisions from former Vice President Kamala Harris and U.S. Sen. Alex Padilla have been made.

Does that mean the race for California‚Äôs next governor ‚Äî with its primary just six months away ‚Äî is ready to heat up?

It‚Äôs been a rather lackluster campaign thus far. One that, while it certainly is not wanting for candidates, has lacked a certain excitement.

That‚Äôs in part due to the Proposition 50 special election that stole the political attention in the latter part of 2025. But a missing star power in the race to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom has also contributed to what political experts have considered to be a relatively dull gubernatorial campaign.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an open race,‚Äù said Matt Lesenyie, who teaches political science at Cal State Long Beach. ‚ÄúNo big splashes so far.‚Äù

Already, as 2025 comes to a close, a few of the crowded field of Democratic contenders to succeed Newsom have begun to drop out of the race.

Those left include former U.S. Health Secretary Xavier Becerra, State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond and former State Controller Betty Yee, all of whom have experience in California‚Äôs executive branch.

There‚Äôs former Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, who once served as an advisor to Newsom, and billionaire environmentalist Tom Steyer, whose money will enable him to put his face and name before voters, perhaps a bit more easily.

And then there are Rep. Eric Swalwell and former Rep. Katie Porter, both bringing congressional expertise to the race as well as an affinity for cable television appearances.

As for the Republicans, both Riverside County Sheriff Chad Bianco and former Fox News host Steve Hilton have found a path toward the top of recent polls ‚Äî polls that, notably, show the undecided category still the most popular choice for those surveyed.

There‚Äôs also the possibility that Attorney General Rob Bonta or billionaire businessman Rick Caruso could jump into the fray as well. And while their presence certainly wouldn‚Äôt shake up the campaign with the same weight that Harris or Padilla would have, politicos watching California‚Äôs gubernatorial race believe they could still make some difference.

So no, the race for California governor isn‚Äôt lonely. Just lackluster ‚Äî and that is odd.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs notable about this race is how extraordinarily unsettled it is,‚Äù said Dan Schnur, who teaches political messaging at USC and UC Berkeley.

‚ÄúThere hasn‚Äôt been a campaign for California governor in modern political history that has been so open-ended at this stage,‚Äù Schnur said.

Sen. Tony Strickland, R-Huntington Beach, agrees.

‚ÄúThis is the first time I can recall that there‚Äôs not a clear-cut frontrunner,‚Äù Strickland said.

How will that change in 2026?

Lesenyie expects the field to winnow a bit more: ‚ÄúCampaigns are expensive, poll results and donor energy will dictate these withdrawals.‚Äù

He also believes cost of living will be the issue that really drives the campaign in 2026.

‚ÄúIn the 2022 gubernatorial ‚Ä¶ this manifested as a ‚Äòhomelessness crisis,‚Äô which is true, but retrospectively is also a proxy for cost of living,‚Äù Lesenyie said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd expect the issue framing to tie to retail goods, rent and housing stock.‚Äù

Strickland, meanwhile, said candidates on either side of the aisle who focus on affordability and public safety could set themselves apart. And for him, that also means looking critically at the money California is spending on certain projects, like the high-speed rail project that was billed, years ago, as a train that would quickly connect Los Angeles, the Central Valley, San Francisco and other communities.

Given, in particular, the lack of a strong frontrunner on the Democratic side at this point in the race, Strickland sees the possibility for a Republican to make it through the June primary.

That‚Äôs not unheard of in modern elections in a California where the latest data shows 44.93% of voters are registered Democrats, while only 25.22% are Republicans and 22.6% are no party preference. In the race for an open U.S. Senate seat in California in 2024, Republican Steve Garvey advanced to the general election with then-Rep. Adam Schiff, a Democrat who ultimately won in a landslide.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always said the Democrats have to make some mistakes and a Republican has to run a perfect campaign,‚Äù Strickland, who has endorsed Hilton for governor, said. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs as insurmountable as other people say.‚Äù

But Stephen Cloobeck, a businessman who was running for California governor but ended his campaign in November, said the recent redistricting campaign foreshadows that it will be a Democrat who prevails in the race, despite the uncertainty now.

Statewide, 64.4% of those who voted in the special election agreed to Proposition 50, the redistricting proposal backed by Newsom and other Democrats who marketed it as a referendum on President Donald Trump and his efforts to shore up more congressional seats for Republicans in the 2026 midterms. Only 35.6% of the 11.5 million people who cast ballots opposed redistricting.

‚ÄúIf you do the math, it‚Äôs undeniable,‚Äù said Cloobeck, who is backing Swalwell in the race. ‚ÄúTrump can‚Äôt spend enough money in California to elect a Republican governor. It can‚Äôt happen.‚Äù

In the meantime, Schnur, who has worked on multiple presidential and gubernatorial campaigns, likens the current field of chief executive hopefuls to ‚Äúa political moshpit.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are too many candidates to keep track of, and they‚Äôre all trying to climb over each other and just keep getting pulled back down with the rest of them,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúOnce we move into the election year on the calendar, it becomes slightly easier to get the voters‚Äô attention, but there is no guarantee with all this multi-candidate infighting all the way through the primary.‚Äù

In other words, the race for California governor is still very much unsettled.
news.summary: While the campaign certainly hasn't lacked candidates, it has been missing star power. Could that change in the election year?
news.author: Kaitlyn Schallhorn

news.title: Kennedy magic: America's storied political dynasty roared back in 2025 - USA Today
news.text:
WASHINGTON ‚Äì Stepping inside Kathleen Kennedy Townsend‚Äôs sun-filled apartment is like stepping into American history.

A letter from her father Robert F. Kennedy hangs in the hallway.

"Dear Kathleen, as the oldest of the Kennedy grandchildren you have a special responsibility: Be kind to others and work for your country,‚Äù RFK wrote his 12-year-old daughter, two days after the assassination of his brother, President John F. Kennedy, in 1963.

For members of the Kennedy clan, that sense of responsibility is being tested by one of their own: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Townsend's younger brother and a top member of President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration.

‚ÄúI would not say there‚Äôs a lot of peace in my family,‚Äù she said, alluding to the tragedies and scandals that have preyed on the Kennedy dynasty, including the assassination of her own father in 1968 while running for the Democratic presidential nomination.

That's certainly been true in 2025, the 100th anniversary of Sen. Robert F. Kennedy‚Äôs birth, which saw his namesake accused of spreading vaccine conspiracies and groping a babysitter during a televised Senate confirmation hearing, the release of government files on the JFK and RFK assassinations, and mass firings and scientific turmoil at the Department of Health and Human Services.

Townsend, 74, the oldest grandchild of the Kennedy family matriarch Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy and power broker Joseph Kennedy, is unassuming and friendly. She often puts her arm on the shoulder of a reporter as she offers explanations of framed letters and memorabilia lining her long entryway.

There‚Äôs a large red leather swivel chair in the study that her father sat in when he was the U.S. attorney general. Townsend encourages the visitor to sit and get a feel for the well-worn chair.

Call it the Kennedy magic. The ability to connect with people that has kept America‚Äôs most storied political family at the heart its politics for more than half of its 250-year history.

The clan experienced a generational handoff after Sen. Ted Kennedy, the youngest sibling of JFK and RFK, died in 2009 while in his 47th year serving in the Senate. RFK's oldest son, Joseph Kennedy II, a former congressman, declined to run for the ensuing open Massachusetts Senate seat. His son, Joseph P. Kennedy III‚Äì RFK's grandson ‚Äì served in Congress for four terms but gave up his seat to unsuccessfully run in the Democratic Senate primary in Massachusetts in 2020. There has been no Kennedy in Congress since then.

Now, the Kennedy name is back, but in a manner that has horrified most members of an extended brood that maintains deep and historic ties to the Democratic party. In April 2023, RFK Jr. launched a long-shot Democratic primary challenge against then-President Joe Biden. Six months later, he was running for the White House as an independent before ultimately abandoning his campaign to endorse Trump, the Republican nominee.

After Trump's election, RFK Jr. joined the new Cabinet and rolled out a slew of controversial actions as part of his Make America Healthy Again platform. Multiple Kennedy family members have called their relative out as complicit in ‚Äúcruel‚Äù policies of the Trump administration. There have been newspaper opinion pieces, magazine articles and letters to senators from the family warning against RFK Jr.‚Äôs qualifications, character and policies.

It‚Äôs not just MAHA. The family has been buffeted by the release of the JFK and RFK assassination files, while seeing the Kennedy legacy diluted as Trump leveled former first lady Jacqueline Kennedy's garden during his demolition of the East Wing and renamed the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington as the "Trump-Kennedy Center.‚Äù

Maria Shriver, a niece of RFK and JFK, said in a post on X it was ‚Äúbeyond comprehension‚Äù that Trump had sought to ‚Äúrename this great memorial dedicated to President Kennedy."

During an interview with CBS, RFK‚Äôs grandson, Joseph Kennedy III, panned Trump‚Äôs renaming a ‚Äúliving memorial to a fallen president‚Äù like it was a New York City skyscraper.

The year drew to a close with a millennial member of the Kennedy family, Jack Schlossberg - grandson of JFK and an ardent critic of RFK Jr. - announcing a run for an open U.S. House seat from Manhattan.

‚ÄúSEND ME TO CONGRESS TO SMOKE THESE FOOLS- MAKE YOUR VOICE HEARD LOUD AND CLEAR I won‚Äôt back down or be drowned out," Schlossberg wrote Dec. 18 on social media.

'No Irish need apply'

Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy‚Äôs father, John "Honey Fitz" Fitzgerald, was elected as a U.S. congressman from Massachusetts in 1894 and later became Boston‚Äôs first Irish-American mayor.

‚ÄúI spent a lot of time with my grandmother, Rose Kennedy,‚Äù says Townsend. ‚ÄúAnd she would talk about how when she was growing up, there were signs still ‚Äì even though her father was the mayor of Boston ‚Äì that said, 'Help wanted - no Irish need apply.'‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I think that she passed that on to her children as well,‚Äù Townsend said of her privileged family. ‚ÄúWhat injustice feels like.‚Äù

The Kennedy legacy that Rose Kennedy helped forge with her husband continues to shape American politics.

It‚Äôs that sense of justice that led JFK to initiate the push for a bill aimed at ending discriminatory quotas and a preference for northern Europeans, says Townsend. President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Immigration and Nationality Act in 1965, two years after Kennedy's assassination. Ted Kennedy, who won a special election in 1962 to fill the seat his brother vacated to become president, championed it in Congress.

Fredrik Logevall, a professor of history at Harvard University, is writing a multi-volume biography of John F. Kennedy. He said part of the reason the Kennedys are such an extraordinary American story is that the close-knit family shares a political philosophy and an optimistic view of what America could achieve.

Logevall described JFK‚Äôs brand of Democratic politics as ‚Äúpragmatic liberalism,‚Äù RFK as deeply committed to liberalism and Ted Kennedy as left of center.

'Betrayal' of Robert F. Kennedy's legacy

But the common thread was that ‚Äúthey had faith in America, in this flawed, but real democracy,‚Äù Logevall said, adding: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why up until this moment, the Kennedys were in agreement with one another politically.‚Äù

With his role as a top lieutenant to Trump and his embrace of the bombastic MAGA movement, Logevall said RFK Jr. ‚Äúis out of step with what the Kennedy family has stood for politically and continues to stand for.‚Äù

In November, Maxwell Kennedy wrote a searing opinion article in the Boston Globe accusing his older brother, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., of a "betrayal" of their father's legacy by supporting the Trump administration's cuts to food assistance programs for ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs neediest.‚Äù

An environmental attorney for about 30 years, RFK Jr's embrace of Trump has mystified his family. During his first term, Trump's administration rolled back more than 100 environmental rules. Tapping RFK Jr. to join his second term, Trump promised to let him ‚Äúgo wild‚Äù on health, food and medicine.

"Donald Trump is anathema to everything our family stands for," Kerry Kennedy, one of RFK Jr.'s siblings, told USA TODAY in August 2024. "I distance myself and reject everything that Bobby is doing and saying because I think that it's a rejection of our family's values and everything that I've spent my life working for....And, frankly, everything Bobby spent his life working for."

If her father and uncle were still alive, they‚Äôd have detested everything about Trump, Kerry Kennedy added in the interview where she described her plans to stump for Kamala Harris, who by then had replaced Biden as the Democratic nominee.

Responding before Election Day 2024 to his family's criticism, RFK Jr. told Fox News that he understood that his relatives were troubled by his decisions. "But, you know, I think we all need to be able to disagree with each other and still love each other,‚Äù he said.

'God sent me President Trump'

Less than 10 days after Trump won his second term as president, he tapped Robert F. Kennedy Jr., to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.

Kennedy‚Äôs nomination faced fierce resistance from many in the scientific community over his promotion of unfounded claims about vaccines causing autism and antidepressants being linked to school shootings. On the eve of Kennedy's confirmation hearing, his cousin and the only living child of JFK posted a video on social media calling Kennedy a "predator."

‚ÄúI have known Bobby my whole life," Caroline Kennedy said in the video, in which she read aloud a letter she wrote to senators who'd be voting on RFK Jr.'s nomination. "We grew up together. It‚Äôs no surprise that he keeps birds of prey as pets because he himself is a predator."

RFK Jr. did not respond to Caroline Kennedy's allegation.

Following Senate approval as one of Trump‚Äôs Cabinet picks, RFK Jr. was sworn into his new job during an Oval Office ceremony surrounded by his wife, actress Cheryl Hines, and his children.

"For 20 years, I'm up every morning on my knees and praying that God would put me in a position where I can end the childhood chronic disease epidemic in this country," he said. "God sent me President Trump." 

Over the last 11 months, Kennedy has made sweeping changes to vaccines, food and prescription drug policies. He's also targeted ultra-processed foods, linking them to chronic diseases like obesity, diabetes and certain cancers. 

RFK Jr‚Äôs MAHA policies around food regulation and limiting animal testing have found broad bipartisan support from the American public, according to polls. That's in contrast to his policies around vaccines and severe funding cuts to HHS, which have been roundly criticized by scientists and lawmakers of both parties. In March, Kennedy announced the consolidation of divisions and elimination of 20,000 full-time employees in a major restructuring, saying it would save taxpayers $1.8 billion per year.

In June, Kennedy removed all 17 members of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's expert vaccine panel and filled many of the positions with people who have been vaccine skeptics or questioned COVID-19 vaccine mandates.

Public criticism, once again, came from his family. In a New Yorker essay headlined 'A battle with my blood,' Tatiana Schlossberg, the granddaughter of JFK and daughter of Caroline Kennedy, revealed that she had less than a year to live. She minced no words.

"As I spent more and more of my life under the care of doctors, nurses, and researchers striving to improve the lives of others, I watched as Bobby cut nearly a half billion dollars for research into mRNA vaccines, technology that could be used against certain cancers," wrote Schlossberg, 35, who is undergoing treatment for a rare form of blood cancer. "Slashed billions in funding from the National Institutes of Health, the world‚Äôs largest sponsor of medical research."

Schlossberg wrote that despite her mother‚Äôs letter to the Senate and her brother, Jack Scholssberg, speaking out ‚Äúagainst his lies for months, I watched from my hospital bed as Bobby, in the face of logic and common sense, was confirmed for the position, despite never having worked in medicine, public health, or the government."

Holding on to the legacy of feeling others' pain

Given that RFK Jr. currently holds the most high-profile political position in the famed family, where does that leave the Kennedy legacy?

For her part, Townsend, a former lieutenant governor of Maryland, has made it her mission to advocate for strong regulations and accountability in the tech industry. She currently serves as an advisor for a nonprofit called Guard Rail Now to help states develop AI regulations.

The oldest of 11 children, Townsend was 16 years old when her father was assassinated. As far as the family legacy, she says each member has the "obligation to make our country fairer, more just, and to give back."

Being the oldest, has she ever thought of herself as the peacekeeper in the family? Townsend said she didn‚Äôt see it that way. ‚ÄúI don't know if this search for peace is really an appropriate way to live,‚Äù she replied. ‚ÄúI think it's more important to feel other people's pain and your own pain."

It‚Äôs also important to feel joy when joy is appropriate, Townsend said, a lesson she learned from her mother, who with a sense of humor and a zest for life raised the large family after her husband‚Äôs assassination.

‚ÄúJoy is not peaceful. Joy is enthusiasm," Townsend said, adding with a laugh: "My mother didn't go around looking for peace. She felt joy and excitement and thrill and a desire to win at tennis - that's not peace."

While family members might have differing definitions of patriotism, one thing is clear: The Kennedys do not shy away from being public about what they believe is right. Maintaining family peace is not the priority.

Swapna Venugopal Ramaswamy is a White House correspondent for USA TODAY. You can follow her on X @SwapnaVenugopal
news.summary: Kennedy magic: America's storied political dynasty roared back in 2025  USA Today
news.author: Swapna Venugopal Ramaswamy

By CHARLOTTE DEAN, ASSOCIATE SHOWBUSINESS EDITOR 
 Published:09:51 EST, 28 December 2025 |Updated:10:22 EST, 28 December 2025 

Andy Carroll has shared an insight into his Christmas with Lou Teasdale after being charged with breaching a non-molestation order after being arrested at an airport. 
The former Newcastle and Liverpool striker, 36, posted highlights from the festive season with his girlfriend, 42, and the rest of his family on Instagram on Saturday.
The post came shortly after the news that Andy had breached the order after being arrested in April, with the alleged offences relating to an incident in March. He is due to appear in court on December 30.
But there appeared to be no sign of drama in his latest upload, as the sportsman shared loved-up pictures with Lou from Christmas day.
Andy and Lou, who started dating late last year, wore festive accessories and snuggled up next to a Christmas tree looking every inch the perfect couple.
Lou was wearing an Adidas Originals top and paper crown, while Andy was sporting a green knit T-shirt with a red santa hat.

Other photographs showed the couple catching a football game, with Lou tucking into a king sized Pot Noodle while watching the match.
Elsewhere the couple posed for a fun snap in a supermarket camera and huddled around the table for Christmas dinner in another.
Andy captioned the carousel of photos: 'Christmas Carroll's'. 
Andy is currently dating make-up artist Lou after parting ways with his estranged wife Billi Mucklow in 2024.
Andy split from his TOWIE star ex Billi, 37, in July last year after a turbulent two year marriage. They began divorce proceedings in September this year. 
Just weeks after their split, he went public with Lou, having reportedly met at Glastonbury in June the same year.
The selection of photos come after Andy was reportedly pounced on by police shortly after landing in the UK from France at Stansted Airport.
He was questioned by officers and held for a short period, a source told the Sun at the time of his arrest.

'It seemed as if an issue was flagged up to the Border Force officers at passport control at Stansted, which led to police being called. He was questioned then taken away,' they said. 
'It caused quite a kerfuffle as there were lots of other passengers around where he was arrested.'
Essex Police told the newspaper: 'A man has been charged with breaching a non-molestation order. 
'Andrew Carroll, 36, of Epping, was arrested on April 27 and the alleged offences relate to an incident in March. 
'He is due to appear at Chelmsford magistrates' court on December 30.' 
Carroll, who earned nine England caps during his career, is currently playing for non-league side Dagenham and Redbridge.
The striker joined the National League South side in the summer, after returning to England following spells at French clubs Amiens and Bordeaux.

news.title: "Hail and farewell": A tribute to those we lost in 2025
news.text: It felt like those we lost this year were as numerous as raindrops. Luminaries like Robert Redford, who challenged Hollywood to do better, to think harder, to take risks.He was of Hollywood, but he preferred to live away from it. His Sundance Film Institute and Festival gave independent filmmakers a bit of sun at Sundance, promoting what he told "Sunday Morning" in 2018 were "the smaller stories. The more offbeat stories. The more controversial."Robert Redford: An appreciation ("Sunday Morning")From the archives: Three interviews with Robert Redford ("Sunday Morning")Gallery: Robert Redford 1936-2025Redford lived long enough to see fellow Oscar-winner Gene Hackman pass away. Hackman shone just as brightly. He could be gentle, as in "Hoosiers," and powerful, as in "The French Connection."Remembering two-time Oscar-winner Gene Hackman ("Sunday Morning")From 2000: Gene Hackman, actor, novelist ("Sunday Morning")The real-life heroes from the civil rights movement are sadly getting more scarce every day. Sam Moore's song "Soul Man" was meant to show pride and resilience.From 2014: Sam Moore, of Sam & Dave ("Sunday Morning")And there was one person who lived those values for 111 years: Viola Fletcher, the oldest witness to the Tulsa Race Massacre. Then there was Charles Person, the youngest among the original famed "Freedom Riders" protest in 1961. Joseph McNeil took a stand ‚Ä¶ by sitting, at a Whites-only Woolworth's lunch counter. Jo Ann Allen, one of the "Clinton 12," was among the first to endure the desegregation of schools all across the South. Bobby Cain was, too. He became the first Black student to graduate under those conditions.A decade later, courage like that inspired the likes of Jesse Colin Young and the Youngbloods to record a song with a message of belonging, "Get Together." "Come on people now,Smile on your brother,Everybody get together,Try to love one another right now"The song permeated the Summer of Love. The late Sly Stone, of Sly and the Family Stone, got on board the inclusion train, too, with his song "Everyday People." He certainly had an ear for the times. Remembering Sly Stone ("Sunday Morning")From 2023: The reclusive Sly Stone returns, on the page ("Sunday Morning")Dick Cheney, who had an ear for politics, started his career the same year that song came out. He went on to become the most influential Vice President in history, especially in the wake of the September 11, 2001 terror attacks. Asked by "Sunday Morning" in 2015 if he was changed by the events of that day, Cheney replied, "Well, it's been alleged by some of my friends that 9/11 did change Cheney, that when he was a Secretary of Defense in the first Bush administration, he was a warm, pleasant, lovable fellow, and he became more of a hard rock afterwards. And I think that's probably true."He remained a staunch conservative ‚Äì until, that is, 2024, when he voted for Democrat Kamala Harris. From 2009: The Cheney Exit Interview ("Face the Nation")That's similar to Supreme Court Justice David Souter. Nominated by President George H.W. Bush, he leaned more to the left in his later years. He left us at 85.Passage: Remembering Justice David Souter ("Sunday Morning")Right in the middle was Senator Alan Simpson, who balanced his conservative views with more moderate stands -- a plain-spoken cowboy from the plains of Wyoming who got his wings at 93.Alan Simpson and Norman Mineta: A friendship born in one of America's darkest hours ("Sunday Morning")Peter Yarrow, of Peter Paul and Mary, got his wings this year, too. The tenor who helped bridge the gap between folk and pop was 86.From 2004: Peter Yarrow and John Kerry's long strange tripJimmy Cliff ("I Can See Clearly Now") bridged another gap: helping make reggae mainstream. The former choir boy from Jamaica found some of his inspiration in the traditions of gospel music, such as "Many Rivers to Cross."Pope Francis crossed that final river this year ‚Äì a day after he blessed the faithful in St. Peter's Square on Easter Sunday.The "People's Pope": The future of Pope Francis' legacy ("Sunday Morning")From 2017: St. Francis + Pope Francis ("Sunday Morning")Whether you believe in Heaven as a destination or not, there's no doubt the heavens are unending. Astronaut James Lovell never landed on the moon, but saw it closer than most. He took to the skies for the last time at age 97.Remembering pioneering astronaut Jim Lovell ("CBS Saturday Morning")From 2018: How Apollo 8 sent a timeless holiday greeting from the heavens ("Sunday Morning")Back on Earth, astrophysicist Fred Espenak was chasing our galaxy with a telescope. He witnessed the moon blot out the sun 52 times ‚Äì a sci-fi experience in real life.Preparing for the Great American Eclipse of 2017 ("Sunday Morning")We lost others who imagined life beyond the stars ‚Äì in movie posters. Drew Struzan was the artist behind the theater posters for the "Star Wars" films and the "Back to the Future" trilogy. Renato Casaro gave life to blockbusters like "Rambo" and "Terminator 2."From 2022: An 86-year-old movie poster artist's unlikely third act ("CBS Mornings")And then there was Joe Caroff, the artist who created the James Bond logo.We also lost some who appeared in those classic Bond films ‚Äì tough guys like Bruce Glover, the assassin in "Diamonds Are Forever"; and Joe Don Baker, the arms dealer in "The Living Daylights." And so many, many more: Graham Greene ("Dances With Wolves"); Enzo Staiola ("Bicycle Thieves"); Pat Crowley ("Forever Female"); Patrick Adiarte ("The King and I"); Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa ("Mortal Kombat"); Michael Madsen ("Reservoir Dogs"); and Sally Kirkland ("Anna").We lost Rebekah Del Rio, that unforgettable singer in "Mulholland Drive," the same year that we lost director David Lynch who put her in that film. In 2016 Lynch told "Sunday Morning" that people should not confuse the characters in his movies with his state of mind: "Stories are stories," he said. "And like I say, the artist doesn't have to suffer to show suffering."Remembering visionary filmmaker David LynchOscar-nominee Diane Ladd offered plenty of suffering in Lynch's "Wild at Heart." Her daughter, Laura Dern, and the rest of her fans mourned her loss at 89.From 2023: Diane Ladd and Laura Dern: A mother and daughter with much to say ("Sunday Morning")Sharing a spot on the Hollywood Walk of Fame with Ladd, far from the beach, was the Beach Boys' Brian Wilson. Wilson was called the poet laureate of surf culture. Remembering Brian Wilson ("Sunday Morning")From 2015: Brian Wilson's summer of milestones ("Sunday Morning")From 2012: The Beach Boys: Back catching another wave ("Sunday Morning")But when it came to the poetry of baseball, there were few better than Bob Uecker. He was a ballplayer who became "Mr. Baseball," a pioneer for his wit and self-deprecating humor. Asked by "Sunday Morning" in 2024 his favorite Bob Uecker line, he replied, "Just a bit outside. That's where my wife put me a lot of times!"Nina Kuscsik was left outside of the men in marathons ‚Äì until, that is, she became the first woman to enter the New York City Marathon, and the first official female winner of the Boston Marathon.From 2022: The Six Who Sat reflect on the 1972 New York City Marathon that made history ("CBS Saturday Morning")In figure skating, Dick Button was the first to land a double axel, and the first American to bring home gold in Olympic figure skating ‚Äì twice. Button was elegant and fierce, much the way George Foreman was in the boxing ring. He got a heavyweight world title in his 20s ‚Äì and then unbelievably again in his 40s. And even if you never saw him box, you probably saw him cook. He described his George Foreman Grill as a real "knockout."From 2005: Boxer and grill pitchman George Foreman ("Sunday Morning")Another ringmaster ‚Äì and master marketer - was Hulk Hogan, the face of professional wrestling for decades. He was the ultimate showman, who died of cardiac arrest at age 71.There were, this year, so many unnatural deaths, especially, it seems, on college campuses, from Brown University just before Christmas, to Utah Valley University, where political activist Charlie Kirk was murdered. He was there organizing young voters around Christian conservative values. The students who saw what happened will never be the same. Anne Marie Hochhalter survived the mass shooting at Columbine High School in 1999, but 26 years later it caught up with her. She died from injuries related to the shooting that left her paralyzed. She was only 43.It's hard to fathom just how much life does come after a tragedy. John Cleary was shot on the campus of Kent State University, a moment captured in a Life Magazine photo. But he ended up finishing his degree in architecture. He lived another 55 years.We lost others in architecture, too. David Childs designed the Freedom Tower in the wake of 9/11.From 2011: David Childs and the view from 1 WTC ("Sunday Morning")We lost Frank Gehry, perhaps the most recognizable American architect since Frank Lloyd Wright. Passage: Remembering architect Frank Gehry ("Sunday Morning")From the archives: Architect Frank Gehry ("Sunday Morning")And then there was Giorgio Armani, an architect of fashion, who turned red carpet events into press conference. Who was wearing him got a lot of coverage. Passage: Remembering fashion designer Giorgio Armani ("Sunday Morning")From 2006: Designer Giorgio Armani ("Sunday Morning")So many of those who asked the questions trying to get answers about all kinds of things left us this year, like our colleague Mark Knoller. With his booming voice, and a treasure trove of presidential trivia, he gave CBS' White House coverage a real spark. Morris Banks, a cameraman who was equally intimidating in stature, travelled the world for CBS to brings us stories of people and events. The same was true of "Sunday Morning"'s Jim McLaughlin. And indeed, so many, many more: CBS cameraman Dave Dorsett; William Galbraith, chief editor, CBS News, Washington; CBS News producer, editor and writer Jerry Mazza; Chuck Milton, of CBS Sports; CBS News correspondent Ed Rabel; CBS News editor Seth Fox; Belva Davis, anchor, CBS News in San Francisco; Peter Arnett of CNN; and NPR's Susan Stamberg. Asked by "Sunday Morning" in 2021 about the future of radio, Stamberg replied, "People will always listen and want to hear stories told by human voices."Human voices, sometimes shouting in the wilderness, can do remarkably good things, even if those voices are voicing pain. Virginia Giuffre was the first of Jeffrey Epstein's victims to go public. Soon, other survivors joined her. They began speaking with one voice ‚Äì shining lights in the dark. In 2020 she told "CBS This Morning," "The buck stops when every single monster gets held accountable and our children are safe. And we need everyone's help."Giuffre was just 41.Jeffrey Epstein survivor Virginia Giuffre, in her own words ("Sunday Morning")Conservationist Jane Goodall raised her voice from the jungles of East Africa, where her work with chimpanzees made us look at ourselves ‚Äì and our relationship with the animal kingdom ‚Äì in a different and special way. In 1990 she said, "We're not quite as different from the rest of the animal kingdom as we used to think."Passage: Remembering Jane Goodall ("Sunday Morning")From 2021: Jane Goodall on her hope for the future ("Sunday Morning")In fact, animals can seem every bit as human as we are. June Lockhart played Lassie's "mom," among a lot of other roles. She was always just as intuitive as Lassie herself.That Golden Era of TV started the career of Rob Reiner, too, and while he was a good actor, it was directing where he really made his mark. Name some of your favorite movies and chances are Reiner directed them. From comedy ("This Is Spinal Tap," "When Harry Met Sally," "The Princess Bride"), to drama ("Misery," "A Few Good Men"), he had his finger on our pulse the way few people did.Rob Reiner, and his wife Michele, left us far too soon. Remembering the treasured films of Rob Reiner ("Sunday Morning")From the archives: Three with Rob Reiner ("Sunday Morning")Another familiar face was George Wendt. As Norm on "Cheers," there's no wonder everybody knew his name. Wendt was 76.Patrons of real-life Cheers mourn George Wendt's death, "drink a beer for Norm"We also lost David Ketchum from "Get Smart"; and Malcolm Jamal Warner, from "The Cosby Show." It's hard to think of any of them getting any older. Take TV's Dennis the Menace: Child actor Jay North couldn't stay young forever. He was 73 when he died at his home in Florida.And then there was actor Richard Chamberlain, who played the young intern Dr. Kildare. He went on to star in blockbuster TV miniseries like "Shogun" and "The Thorn Birds."Both those novels hit the bestseller list ‚Äì and so did the "Confessions of a Shopaholic" series, authored by Madeleine Wickham, who wrote under the pen-name Sophie Kinsella.In 2014 she told "CBS This Morning," "You're hoping that people will enjoy your book, but you don't know, and off it goes. But then you meet somebody who says 'Well you know what, I ,,read your book in the middle of the night while I was recovering from operation, and it got me through.' I mean, how could you do anything better in life than that?" The British author died of brain cancer at just 55.Few British playwrights have been compared to Shakespeare, but Tom Stoppard was. In 1999 he told "Sunday Morning," "It seemed to me that having a play on at the National Theatre, for example, was some kind of Everest which only a chosen few could ever even hope to aspire to. It turns out to be something that can happen to people like me."He was 88 when he slipped this mortal coil. For all the creative writers and performers that we did lose this year, we were really struck by the sheer number of TV personalities who passed away: Polly Holliday ("Alice"); Loni Anderson ("WKRP in Cincinnati"); Lulu Roman ("Hee-Haw"); Ruth Buzzi ("Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In"); Prunella Scales ("Fawlty Towers"); Danielle Spencer ("What's Happening!!"); Lynne Marie Stewart ( "Pee-Wee's Playhouse"); and Loretta Swit ("M*A*S*H"). Portrayals of those in our nation's uniform rarely get better than "M*A*S*H" or, later, "Top Gun." Few could top Tom Cruise as a cocky Naval aviator, but Val Kilmer did. He played so many other roles, from Jim Morrison of The Doors, to Doc Holliday in "Tombstone." "I like characters," Kilmer told "Sunday Morning" in 2013. "I think that's what people have enjoyed most in my acting." But it was "Iceman" that stuck with all of us right till the very end. Val Kilmer was 65.Airmen who saw real combat in World War II are few and far between these days, like John "Lucky" Luckadoo. They called him that because he survived so much, and he continued to, making it to 103.World War II veteran John "Lucky" Luckadoo reflects on his serviceFrom 2024: World War II veterans speak to the ages ("Sunday Morning")Joe Harris lived to 108 ‚Äì one of the oldest WWII paratroopers.From 2024: World War II veteran celebrates 108th birthday in ComptonGeorge Hardy earned his wings at just 19, making him one of the youngest Tuskegee Airmen. Jessie Mahaffey survived the attack on Pearl Harbor ‚Äì and the sinking of another ship just a year later. he was 102. Donald McPherson distinguished himself as an "ace" in the skies above Okinawa. Julia Parsons, one of the last Enigma code breakers, left us, too, this, year.Some, however, never came home, but Vietnam POW Lt Col. Robert Stirm finally did. The Pulitzer Prize-winning picture said it all ‚Äì his family seeing his face for the first time in almost six years.Words never matched those feelings, but lyricist Alan Bergman's words got pretty close. He and his wife, co-writer Marilyn Bergman, are perhaps best known for the classic "The Way We Were."So many couples we remember the way they were, like Dorothy Vogel and her late husband Herb. On modest means, upstairs in their rent-controlled apartment, they amassed an art collection worth millions. True to their modesty, before their deaths, they gave most of it away. What Rick Davies gave away was his artistry behind the Wurlitzer electric piano. It gave the supergroup Supertramp its signature chart-topping sound. He was 81.We lost "Space Ace" ‚Äì Ace Frehley ‚Äì of the heavy metal group Kiss this year, too. He made fans believe his playing really did make his guitar smoke (and maybe it did!). And then there was Ozzy Osbourne, the lead singer of Black Sabbath and self-described Prince of Darkness. His wife, Sharon Osbourne, stayed with him through thick and thin. Asked by "Sunday Morning" in 2012 what their secret was, Ozzy replied, "I don't know. You know, I'm in the rock and roll. Because you rock and you roll. You know, you just get on with it."Looking back on Ozzy Osbourne's life and legacyThose musicians who have just "gone with it," like D'Angelo and Connie Francis, still left us their talents that make us, as trumpeter Chuck Mangione did, feel "so good" ... like Bobby Sherman ("Julie, Do Ya Love Me"); John Lodge of The Moody Blues ("Nights in White Satin"); and Marianne Faithfull ("As Tears Go By");From 2009: Marianne Faithfull on the hard road to becoming a legend ("Sunday Morning")There was also singer and guitarist Wayne Osmond of The Osmonds ("Crazy Horses"), and Mark Volman of The Turtles ("Happy Together")."Happy together" just might describe what most people were feeling when they were in the company of the legendary Diane Keaton. Some called her quirky, even kooky. But everyone agreed she was talented beyond measure. She could do searing dramas and romantic comedies, always holding her own with the best of them. "I think that one of the reasons I've been able to be around for as long as I have, is because I have been in funny movies," she told "Sunday Morning" in 2010.She left her mark not only as an actor, but with her fashion sense, too.From 2010: Diane Keaton on Woody Allen, "Annie Hall," and marriage ("Sunday Morning")Keaton was certainly unique, as most of those we remember are. There are far too many to name. But for their talents, their passions, their love and care and influence, we are forever grateful.To all of them we bid a very fond "Hail, and Farewell." Story produced by Young Kim. Editor: Steve Tyler. Digital producer: David Morgan.For images thanks to: The National WWII MuseumThe World War II FoundationMatthew Brown, Bob Christy and Kent State University
news.summary: "Sunday Morning" looks back at some of the newsworthy men and women who passed away this year ‚Äì from musicians and storytellers, to activists and statesmen ‚Äì who touched us with their creativity and humanity.
news.author: Lee Cowan
